importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Hamas attack on Israel that led to the abduction of hostages and the subsequent hostage crisis.
The estimated date when Arye Zalmanovich was believed to have been killed in captivity by Hamas.
The date the US-proposed ceasefire agreement was signed, which mandated the return of hostages, including deceased ones.
The date when the bodies of two deceased hostages were returned to Israel from Gaza.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from the initial Hamas attack through the ongoing hostage recovery efforts and ceasefire implementation, highlighting the duration of the conflict and recovery process.

keyTakeAways: Hamas returned the bodies of two deceased hostages — Arye Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar — to Israel on October 22, 2025, following the US-proposed ceasefire agreement.

Arye Zalmanovich, aged 85, was the oldest hostage taken by Hamas and was killed in captivity on November 17, 2023; he was a founding member of Kibbutz Nir Oz and a respected farmer and community leader.
Tamir Adar, aged 38, died defending his kibbutz on October 7, 2023, and his body was taken to Gaza; he was described as a family man, educator, and nature lover.
The return of the bodies is part of a broader ceasefire agreement under the Trump administration, which required Hamas to return all deceased hostages within 72 hours of the deal’s activation.
Hamas has acknowledged difficulty in recovering all bodies due to rubble and incomplete information, and one previously returned body was misidentified, raising concerns about compliance.

US Vice President JD Vance emphasized the importance of returning the bodies for proper burial, while noting it would not happen overnight and that some remains are buried under rubble or lost in the conflict zones.
The return of these bodies represents both a humanitarian and symbolic effort to honor victims and bring closure to grieving families.

namedEntities.name: Arye Zalmanovich
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An 85-year-old Israeli man who was abducted by Hamas during the October 7, 2023 attacks and was the oldest hostage taken by Hamas. He was a founder of Kibbutz Nir Oz and a farmer.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was one of the first deceased hostages returned to Israel, marking a significant milestone in the recovery of human remains under the ceasefire agreement.

namedEntities.name: Tamir Adar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 38-year-old Israeli man who died defending Kibbutz Nir Oz on October 7, 2023. His body was taken to Gaza and later returned to Israel.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His return highlights the broader effort to recover deceased hostages, and he is remembered as a beloved family man, educator, and nature enthusiast.

namedEntities.name: Kibbutz Nir Oz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A kibbutz in southern Israel where both Arye Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar lived and where the attacks occurred.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the origin point of the two hostages and the location tied to the attack, community memory, and the personal loss experienced by residents.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Palestinian militant group responsible for the October 7, 2023 attacks on Israel, which led to the abduction of hostages and the subsequent hostage crisis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is responsible for the initial attack, the abductions, and the ongoing responsibility for returning deceased hostages under the ceasefire agreement.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Israeli military responsible for responding to Hamas attacks and managing the recovery of hostages and bodies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF played a key role in confirming the deaths of hostages and in the logistics of bringing the bodies back for identification and burial.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Israeli Prime Minister who publicly acknowledged the grief of the families and confirmed the return of the two bodies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a central political figure whose government oversees the response to the hostage crisis and the implementation of the ceasefire agreement.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The country that proposed and supported a ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas, which includes provisions for returning all deceased hostages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US proposed the ceasefire deal, which mandated the return of bodies, and its officials, like JD Vance, are involved in monitoring compliance.

namedEntities.name: JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The US Vice President who visited Israel and addressed concerns about the return of hostages and the fragile nature of the ceasefire.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He publicly emphasized the importance of returning bodies for burial and acknowledged the difficulty of the recovery process.

namedEntities.name: Hostages and Missing Families Forum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An organization representing families of hostages and missing persons, which provided statements on the personal significance of Zalmanovich and Adar.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provided emotional and human context to the victims and helped frame the humanitarian aspect of the hostage recovery efforts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 22, 2025, Hamas returned the bodies of two deceased hostages — Arye Zalmanovich, the oldest hostage taken during the October 7, 2023 attacks, and Tamir Adar, a kibbutz defender who died in the initial assault — to Israel from Gaza. Both men were from Kibbutz Nir Oz, with Zalmanovich, aged 85, believed to have been killed in captivity in November 2023, and Adar, aged 38, having died in defense of the community. The return of their remains is part of a US-proposed ceasefire agreement signed on October 9, 2025, which required Hamas to return all deceased hostages within 72 hours. The Israeli government and families expressed deep sorrow over the loss. US Vice President JD Vance acknowledged the difficulty of recovering bodies buried under rubble or lost in conflict zones, noting that while progress has been made, the process is not going to happen overnight. The article highlights both the human cost and the ongoing challenges of recovering human remains in a war zone, as well as the political and humanitarian dimensions of the ceasefire effort.
title: Oldest hostage taken by Hamas among two deceased returned to Israel Tuesday
